[3]

dialogues.Damon:
[1]I'm sorry, Starks. Must have not seen you coming there. Were you worried about me? [Smiling] That's so sweet. Thanks. 
[2]Fuck the tranquilizer! I got a foot. 
[3]You got any booze? 
[4]Starks, you're like a mule. You're real stubborn. But there's ways of fixin' that. All you need is a good stick. [Beat] Here's your stick. 
[5]You folks ain't supposed to be down here. 
[6]Do I know you from somewhere? 
[7]That's right! Goddamn, you're the spitting image. I didn't know he had a son. 
[8]Oh yeah, sure. He killed a cop, right? 
[9]Oh yeah, what'd he say? 
[10]Look here, I don't like you getting in my face and saying this bullshit to me... 
[11]I thought you said you never knew your father. 
[12]I don't know what you're talking about, man. I swear. This is some weird shit you're telling me... and I don't know how come you're doing it. 
[13]I never touched your father! I swear! 
[14]No funny business or we can make this a lot fucking harder for you.
dialogues.Mackenzie:
[1]That's Kingsley. Old bastard hears us, I'm sure. He just doesn't want to bother answering so he makes us think he can't talk. I know. I tried it on my mother for two months once before she fished out my tongue. Literally. [Beat] You're the cop killer, right? 
[2]TV. Helps numb [makes a "crazy gesture"] any active mind. [Sticking out a jittery hand] Rudy MacKenzie. 
[3]Welcome to the village, William Starks. 
[4]That's too bad. I don't believe in disposable language either -- you know, the small talk, the little talk. Chit. Chat. Useless. The game's something else though. Think about it: What can we trade with each other in the air between us? This... [running his hand through the air] is our court. [Beat, so eager it's sad] I'm ready to throw the ball. Come on. What are you in here for? 
[5]I tried to kill my wife. 
[6]I tried something like 30 times. 
[7]She's bigger than me, and she's stronger than me. And I never planned on doing it. It was always in the heat of the moment. I didn't beat her or anything. Hell, she beat me. But when we'd start fighting, I'd go for the knife. Then she kept threatening to have me put away, and [looking around] she finally did. 
[8]Or just plain stupid. You'd think by the twentieth time, I'd have found an alternative method. Maybe a more effective one, if you know what I mean. 
[9]It's a hard one for me, Dr. Lorenson. [Finally turns to face her, grimly] The world around me, it's shrinking. There's not even room for light to make its way in. [Beat] Da-da-bum! Da- da-bum! I feel like the horseman of doom is coming for me, Doc. Only today, he's not carrying flowers. 
[10]What? It's better than fine. 
[11]Of course you can, Doc. William, it was an absolute pleasure. Thanks for playing. 
[12]Hey...when they talk you out to the woods tonight and invite the wolves, dance with them. [Beat] They don't eat you when there's music playing. 
[13]When they take you out to the woods tonight and invite the wolves, dance with them. 
[14]They don't eat you when there's music playing. 
[15]I wasn't talking about anything. 
[16]I know you need one when it's really cold. 
[17]Mortality's actually a great thing to be familiar with. It means you're sane on some level. 
[18][Beat] How do you know? 
[19]Oh no, you're pretty young. Your body'll be able to handle a lot more of it than you think... 
[20]It's gonna be sticky. 
[21]'Cause Lorenson's got her claws in it now. When she started getting suspicious about me was when they stopped using it on me. Women! 
[22]You could still always give Becker an itch. 'Course you might get killed when he goes to scratch it, but seems to me you're saying that's about to happen anyway. [Beat] Just be careful not to walk yourself right into something. 
[23]Hey, I brought you some smokes. 
[24]Geez, how's that for a fucking "thank you"? 
[25]She left me, I tried to kill her, I tried to kill myself. She was mean, I was weak, I was cruel so she left, I didn't plan it, didn't see it...FINE! I didn't want to see it. I'm in here because they say I have a nervous condition. [Beat] Well, here's my question, who wouldn't be nervous if they really looked at their life? [Beat] Whose life is that good? 
[26]Not this luckless little mammal's. What difference is it to them? [Beat, slows down] You believe what you want to believe. One version is easier than another so you make it your own. 
[27]I'll tell you this though. However nuts I am, I wasn't nuts enough not to know how wrong it was to put a human being in something like that. 
[28][Shrugging] What if we are? There're crazier things than thinking up fictions for yourself. [Beat] Everyone does it, don't they? Even Becker. That roller coaster car pops more pills than all of Ward 3. 
[29]I've been here for 11 years. It's my neighborhood. 'Course I'm sure. He's as drugged up as the rest of us...I guess he has to be to put up with all this.
[1]William Starks could be blocking the incident. It would explain his well- systematized scheme about the little girl and her mother. A delusion as complex as that can often replace the reality of an incident like this. Officer Harrison'd been shot three times. He was long dead by the time we got there. 
[2]I have heard of Gulf War Syndrome. The medical community is only beginning to gather information about it. 
[3]BETH LORENSON , and DR. GRIES are convened with other STAFF at a routine hospital meeting. These doctors deal in the currency of madness every day and wear the heaviness of that burden on their faces.  
[4]How'd he dodge a conviction? 
[5][Beat] So why isn't he just in the psych ward of the county jail? 
[6]    
[7]Morning, gentlemen. How are you doing today? 
[8]And you, Mr. Starks? I'm fine. 
[9]Mr. MacKenzie, do you think I could talk to Mr. Starks privately? 
[10]So you're ok? What? 
[11]I asked you if you're ok. I don't know. You tell me, Doc. You think there's anything wrong with me? 
[12]I don't know. You're not my patient. 
[13]You look like you've lost some weight. Are you eating? 
[14]Sure. 
[15]Hold him while I get the tranquilizer. 
[16]Wait...Dr. Becker, how long do you want us to leave him in for? 
[17]Just strap him in for now. 
[18]You ok? 
[19][Beat] Listen, I hate to bother you... 
[20]But... what about Starks? 
[21]Should we be... 
[22]But the Jacket? I mean...should we be leaving him in like that? Leaving him in? [Beat] The medication I'm given him is intended to adjust -- maybe even reset -- his violent proclivities. You know, peel away some of those layers of hate. The Jacket's merely a safe place for that to happen. The grounds and the halls -- where I can't monitor side effects I can't predict -- aren't. But, but...what about... But...but what about the gun? I mean, should he have been firing away like that? [Shaking his head at GRIES] You can't fuck up a life that's already been fucked up. [Turning away] There, there's the insurance you're looking for. 
[23]I'm not looking for anything. 
[24]William, can you hear me? 
[25]We never should have done this to him... 
[26]Is he? [Impatiently] Is he dead? 
[27]We're late. 
[28]Maybe it's not such a waste. 
[29]They don't care about all the things we do right. [Beat] But they might ...they might care about what we're doing wrong. [Beat] That's what they should come here to look for. 
[30]They should just be looking harder. 
[31]Later. I'll tell you about it later. We got a session to catch now. 
[32]I'm sorry I can't tell you more about your father's death, Mr. Starks. Our own medical examiners determined only that he died from a blunt trauma to the head but that was right around the time the Alpine Grove's staff changed and I'm afraid we didn't have the best record system before then. 
[33]No, I don't. I'm sorry. I wish I knew more. 
[34]Well, Dr. Lorenson is still here at the hospital. If she was here at the time your father was, then I'm sure she'd be of more help to you. 
[35]Unfortunately, I'm not familiar with Dr. Becker and Dr. Gries passed away three, four years ago. 
[36]Your father was here 12 years ago. I doubt the hospital would have that, if Dr. Becker is still even alive. [Beat, a little suspiciously] Is there a particular reason you need to know how your father died? 
[37]Let me just tell her we're here. 
[38][Beat] What do you need me to do? 
[39]I can't take you out of here in your condition... 
[40]No, it hasn't.
dialogues.Captain:
[1]The level of arms on the ground really depends. [Answering a question] But no, I'd have to say we haven't had to engage on the ground as heavily as we might have expected. 
[2]No. One of my Corporals took a bullet to the head, but it looks like he might make it. Looks that way... 
[3]Sergeant Starks was awarded the Purple Heart. That award doesn't applaud violence or murder. [Beat] It applauds honor. His subconscious is blocking it, the same way it began to in the Gulf, particularly as something similarly traumatizing happened to him then. It's not a question of whether or not he was sane when he did it?! He absolutely was. Three bullets in one man are three moral failings in another. War isn't a CNN Special. Half the shit that went on couldn't be tidied into a top of the hour headline -- either 'cause it couldn't be said neatly or 'cause it couldn't be said at all. It was ugly. And they don't put ugly on TV. [Looking at Starks] If Starks did kill that officer ... [Beat] You can't hold a man responsible for a damaged mind. 
[4]
